title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993". The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, including Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, and Occupational Safety and Health Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, and others. Congress is also subject to the Freedom of Information Act and Independent Counsel Provisions. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, and others. The Act also applies to specific individuals in Congress, such as Senators, Representatives, employees of Congress, elected officers, members of the Capitol Police, and employees of Members whose pay is covered by specific entities. Employees in the district or State office of a Member are subject to the laws set forth in the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993. The Act applies to specific individuals in Congress, including Senators, Representatives, elected officers, members of the Capitol Police, and employees of Members whose pay is covered by specific entities. In section 2, the district or State office is treated as an affiliated branch of a private employer under the laws. A Member may consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring staff. Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed. Small business exemptions apply to Members based on the number of employees. In this subsection, the number of employees attributed to a Member is calculated by adding the employees working in the District of Columbia and employed by the House where the Member sits, then dividing by the number of Members in that House. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by actions under this Act can appeal in Federal court, with rights and remedies as private persons under relevant laws.
